newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil Justice suggests suspension of CVRD auction.
newsitem.headline: Brazil Justice suggests suspension of CVRD auction.

text.p: Brazil's Supreme Court Justice Marco Aurelio de Mello suggested that the April 29 privatization of state mining firm Cia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD) be suspended as a result of a court injunction, local news agency InvestNews said.
The agency quoted Mello as saying the new court injunction would not allow the government to include 411,000 hectares of CVRD's huge Carajas iron mine in the sale.
Mello said the injunction did not require a suspension of the auction, but made the sale pointless.
"If the (National Development Bank) had any sense, the auction should be suspended," the Justice was quoted as saying.

The injunction, sought by opposition lawmakers, was granted by Mello on Tuesday, but still needs to be approved by the full Supreme Federal Tribunal (STF). The date for a hearing by the high court has still not been set.
In a statement, the STF said that, under the constitution, Congress must approve any concession of over 2,500 hectares by the president.

The 411,000 hectares of the Carajas mine were transferred to CVRD in a presidential decree signed by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso on March 6, the same day tender documents for the sale were published.
The Planning Ministry, however, said it is too early to determine if the auction should be suspended.
Carajas, the biggest iron ore deposit in the world with reserves of 15 billion tonnes, is Vale's main mining asset.
An expected bidder on CVRD declined to comment on the ruling or the possibility the auction will be suspended.

"We are waiting to see the details of the (justice's) statement on the injunction," an official at private Brazilian steelmaker Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN), which is leading one of two consortia planning to bid at the auction.
The government plans to sell a maximum 45 percent stake in CVRD and has set a base price of 3.0 billion reais ($2.83 billion). The government hopes to take in at least $5 billion.
